pullRequest.title: [BEAM-9561] Run pandas doctests in parallel.
pullRequest.bodyText:
This significantly speeds up running the full suite.

Thank you for your contribution! Follow this checklist to help us incorporate your contribution quickly and easily:

 Choose reviewer(s) and mention them in a comment (R: @username).
 Format the pull request title like [BEAM-XXX] Fixes bug in ApproximateQuantiles, where you replace BEAM-XXX with the appropriate JIRA issue, if applicable. This will automatically link the pull request to the issue.
 Update CHANGES.md with noteworthy changes.
 If this contribution is large, please file an Apache Individual Contributor License Agreement.

See the Contributor Guide for more tips on how to make review process smoother.

nodes.bodyText: nit: add a help string indicating the default is 0, which will use the cpu count
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -33,10 +39,15 @@
 PANDAS_DIR = os.path.expanduser("~/.apache_beam/cache/pandas-" + PANDAS_VERSION)
 PANDAS_DOCS_SOURCE = os.path.join(PANDAS_DIR, 'doc', 'source')
 
+parallelism = None
+
 
 def main():
-  # Not available for Python 2.
-  import urllib.request
+  parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
+  parser.add_argument('-p', '--parallel', type=int, default=0)

nodes.bodyText: Is this needed because parallelism is used in run_tests? Instead of branching on parallelism inside run_tests could we just make a different method for the parallel vs single-threaded cases?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -74,22 +85,56 @@ def main():
         if any(filter in path for filter in filters):
           paths.append(path)
 
+  # Using a global here is a bit hacky, but avoids pickling issues when used
+  # with multiprocessing.
+  global parallelism

commit.message: Arg docs, cleanup parallelism flag, order tests by size.
